moves.1... c5: and I do my usual defence
moves.2. e5: This is rather unusual. Better to get more pieces out rather than move peice again.
moves.2... Nc6: I develop and attack the pawn.
moves.3. f4: He defends, but again another pawn move rather than get his pieces out.
moves.3... d6: I undermine his pawns and prepare to develop my bishop
moves.4... Bg4: by pinning his knight, I increase the pressure on e5 and I develop a piece.
moves.5. exd6: The pressure becomes too much for him. He takes.
moves.5... Qxd6: I take with the queen, as in catalinmf (1587) vs. wotan_spears (1759) (black won in 47)
moves.6. d3: He protects the pawn on f4 which was attacked by my queen.
moves.6... e5: I open up the centre, as I am ahead in development. I am also following catalinmf (1587) vs. wotan_spears (1759)
moves.7. Qd2: He would be better off following catalinmf (1587) vs. wotan_spears (1759) with 7. fxe5 Nxe5
moves.8... Nd4: This is hard to meet. I am threatening the pawn on f3, but also to take on f4 and he can't take back as I play Nxc2. I think this wins a pawn.
moves.10. Qxf4: and he takes back. Now the question is, should I exchange queens or take on c2 first? I decided it would be best to take on c2 first, as if I exchange queen first, his king can come to d2, and after I take his rook, he moves his knight and he is threatening to take my knight on a1 already. If I take on c2 first I prevent that.
moves.12. Kxc2: At least he gets a knight in return for the queen, and my queen is now attacked.
moves.13. Bd2: He threatens my queen with Re1, pinning my queen against my king
moves.14... Qd4: I take up a nice, centralised post threatening d3
moves.16. Kd1: King walks into a self-pin. Kc1 may have been better.
moves.17. f4: He blocks the attack and opens a diagonal for his bishop
moves.18... Qd4: Queen takes up another nice central role. Qxb2, Bxf4 and Qxf4 are all threatened
moves.19. Nc3: This meets one threat, but removes a defender of d2
moves.19... Bxf4: I take here. He resigns, it is hopeless. If he moves his Re3 his Bd2 is lost. Many thanks for reading this, please rate the annotation and leave a comment or two! Thanks!
